verses.text: Now the Pharisees and some of the scribes who had come from Jerusalem gathered to Jesus.
verses.comment: The presence of both Pharisees and scribes from Jerusalem points to a serious challenge to Jesus' authority by the religious leaders.

verses.text: They noticed that some of his disciples ate their bread with hands that were defiled, that is, unwashed.
verses.comment: The issue here is ritual impurity according to the traditions of the elders, not mere hygiene.

verses.text: For the Pharisees and all the Jews do not eat unless they wash their hands thoroughly, holding to the tradition of the elders.
verses.comment: Mark explains the background for his Gentile audience; 'tradition of the elders' refers to oral rules developed by religious authorities.

verses.text: And when they return from the marketplace, they do not eat unless they wash. There are also many other traditions that they observe, such as the washing of cups, pitchers, and copper vessels.
verses.comment: These rituals symbolized inner purity, yet over time became merely external observances, which Jesus will address.

verses.text: Then the Pharisees and scribes asked him, 'Why do your disciples not walk according to the tradition of the elders, but eat with defiled hands?'
verses.comment: Their focus is not on God's direct commandments, but on human traditions.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Well did Isaiah prophesy about you hypocrites, as it is written: "This people honors me with their lips, but their heart is far from me."'
verses.comment: Jesus applies Isaiah's words directly to his challengers, revealing their lack of true devotion (see also Isa. 29:13).

verses.text: 'In vain do they worship me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men.'
verses.comment: Jesus challenges the elevation of man-made traditions over God's revealed will—a warning to all Christian communities to preserve authentic faith and not replace Divine Revelation with mere human customs.

verses.text: You leave the commandment of God and hold to the tradition of men.
verses.comment: Throughout history, the temptation has been to obey human tradition without discerning genuine apostolic teaching rooted in Christ.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'You have a fine way of setting aside the commandment of God in order to establish your own tradition!'
verses.comment: Here Jesus exposes the priority given to tradition over God's command—urging a return to authentic faith handed down from the apostles.

verses.text: For Moses said, 'Honor your father and your mother,' and, 'Whoever reviles father or mother must surely die.'
verses.comment: Jesus roots his argument in Scripture, affirming the authority of God's written law (Ex. 20:12; Lev. 20:9).

verses.text: But you say, 'If a man tells his father or his mother, "Whatever you would have gained from me is Corban" (that is, given to God),'
verses.comment: Corban refers to an offering dedicated to God, which religious leaders allowed as an excuse to neglect one’s familial duties.

verses.text: then you no longer allow him to do anything for his father or mother,
verses.comment: Human regulations can nullify the heart of the Law, which is love and respect for others, especially one’s family.

verses.text: thus making the word of God void by your tradition that you have handed down. And many such things you do.
verses.comment: Jesus makes clear that even well-intended traditions can undermine true obedience when not aligned with God’s will.

verses.text: Then he called the crowd to him again and said, 'Listen to me, all of you, and understand.'
verses.comment: Jesus turns from the leaders to address all the people, indicating the importance of his teaching for the whole community.

verses.text: There is nothing outside a person that by going into him can defile him, but the things that come out of a person are what defile him.
verses.comment: Here Jesus sets forth a radical principle transcending ritual purity laws—a sign of the coming New Covenant.

verses.text: If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.
verses.comment: A familiar prophetic call, urging listeners not just to hear, but to act. Revelation is both received and lived.

verses.text: When he had entered the house and left the crowd, his disciples asked him about the parable.
verses.comment: Jesus often explained deeper meanings to his disciples in private, showing the ongoing role of living instruction in understanding faith.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'Are you also so lacking in understanding? Don't you see that whatever enters a person from outside cannot defile him,'
verses.comment: Jesus’ followers, too, needed guidance in understanding spiritual realities—a reminder that genuine tradition helps interpret revelation.

verses.text: because it does not enter his heart but his stomach, and is expelled?" Thus he declared all foods clean.
verses.comment: 'Thus he declared all foods clean': Jesus subtly abolishes Old Testament dietary laws. This anticipation of God’s universal plan finds fuller explanation in Acts 10 and Paul's epistles (see Acts 10:15; Col. 2:16).

verses.text: And he said, 'What comes out of a person is what defiles him.'
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes that true purity is a matter of the heart, not simply external behavior.

verses.text: For from within, out of the heart of man, come evil thoughts, sexual immorality, theft, murder, adultery,
verses.comment: The problem is deeper than ritual impurity—sin comes from the fallen human heart (Jer. 17:9).

verses.text: coveting, wickedness, deceit, sensuality, envy, slander, pride, foolishness.
verses.comment: Jesus gives a comprehensive list of sins to show that purity laws cannot cover over the deeper need for inward transformation.

verses.text: All these evil things come from within, and they defile a person.
verses.comment: Here, Jesus clarifies that the righteousness God desires penetrates to the root of the person, not just surface actions.

verses.text: From there he arose and went away to the region of Tyre and Sidon. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know, but he could not be hidden.
verses.comment: Jesus intentionally enters Gentile territory, which foreshadows the extension of salvation to all nations, beyond Israel alone.

verses.text: But immediately a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit heard about him and came and fell at his feet.
verses.comment: This woman shows extraordinary faith by seeking help for her daughter—falling at Jesus’ feet, an act of humility.

verses.text: Now the woman was a Greek, a Syrophoenician by birth. She begged him to cast the demon out of her daughter.
verses.comment: Mark makes clear she is a Gentile, emphasizing that Jesus' ministry will ultimately include all peoples.

verses.text: And he said to her, 'Let the children be fed first, for it is not right to take the children's bread and throw it to the little dogs.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ answer seems harsh, but affirms the primacy of Israel in God's plan; yet his compassion will soon extend to the Gentiles.

verses.text: But she answered him, 'Yes, Lord; yet even the little dogs under the table eat the children's crumbs.'
verses.comment: Her humble answer demonstrates remarkable faith, which will be richly rewarded. This is a model for prayer and humility.

verses.text: And he said to her, 'For this statement you may go your way; the demon has left your daughter.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ word holds authoritative power—he heals at a distance with a simple declaration. This hints at the spiritual authority he entrusts to his followers (see Matt. 10:1).

verses.text: And she went home and found her child lying in bed, and the demon gone.
verses.comment: The miraculous healing confirms Jesus’ divinity and power over evil spirits. It also shows the universality of salvation.

verses.text: Then he returned from the region of Tyre and went through Sidon to the Sea of Galilee, in the region of the Decapolis.
verses.comment: Jesus continues ministering in largely Gentile territories, again foreshadowing the opening of the Church to all nations.

verses.text: They brought to him a man who was deaf and had a speech impediment, and they begged him to lay his hand on him.
verses.comment: The gesture of laying on of hands is a sign of blessing and healing that continues in apostolic communities (see Acts 8:17).

verses.text: Taking him aside from the crowd privately, he put his fingers into his ears, and after spitting, touched his tongue.
verses.comment: Jesus uses physical signs, showing sacramental symbolism—physical actions imparting spiritual grace, a pattern seen later in the apostles.

verses.text: And looking up to heaven, he sighed and said to him, 'Ephphatha,' that is, 'Be opened.'
verses.comment: Jesus prays, then commands in Aramaic, demonstrating his divine power and personal compassion—foretaste of the opening of hearts to the Gospel.

verses.text: And his ears were opened, his tongue was released, and he spoke clearly.
verses.comment: Instant healing reflects Old Testament messianic signs: 'the ears of the deaf unstopped… tongue of the mute sing for joy' (Isa. 35:5-6).

verses.text: Jesus charged them to tell no one. But the more he charged them, the more they proclaimed it.
verses.comment: The 'Messianic secret': Jesus manages the timing of the public revelation of his identity, directing attention to faith over mere spectacle.

verses.text: And they were utterly astonished, saying, 'He has done all things well. He even makes the deaf hear and the mute speak.'
verses.comment: Their final statement echoes prophetic expectation—Jesus fulfills Old Testament messianic prophecy (Isa. 35:5-6). In him, divine authority and compassion meet, revealing who he truly is.
